questions.text: Which of the following should not be prescribed with theophylline?
Which of the following drugs gets deposited in the cornea?
questions.explanation:
Chloroquine

MOA

Chloroquine accumulates in acidic compartments of parasite-infected cells, disrupting heme polymerisation and inhibiting parasite growth and replication.

Resistance

Due to mutations in genes encoding transporters involved in chloroquine uptake and efflux, reducing chloroquine accumulation within parasites.

Uses
  • Malaria Treatment and Prophylaxis
  • Amebiasis
  • Leprae reaction
  • Giardiasis
  • Autoimmune Diseases (RA, SLE)

S/E
  • Ophthalmic: Bull's eye maculopathy, anterior subcapsular cataract, vortex keratopathy, corneal deposits
  • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea
  • Skin: Itching, rash, photosensitivity
  • Neuropsychiatric: Agitation, confusion, hallucinations
  • Cardiac: QT prolongation, cardiomyopathy (rare)

questions.text: Voriconazole is not effective against which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Voriconazole

It is a triazole antifungal known for its broad spectrum against yeast and moulds.

MOA

Inhibits fungal sterol 14α-demethylase, disrupting ergosterol synthesis in fungal cell membranes.

Spectrum

Broad spectrum against various fungi

  • Candida albicans (Option A)
  • Candida tropicalis (Option B)
  • Aspergillosis (Option D)

Adverse Effects

Common: Nausea, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, headache, dizziness.

Rare: Anaemia, neutropenia, cardiac arrhythmias, visual disturbances.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of resistance by lactamases to Beta-lactam antibiotics?
questions.explanation:
ß-lactam antibiotics

MOA

ß-lactam antibiotics inhibit the last step in peptidoglycan synthesis by acylating the transpeptidase via cleavage of the -CO-N-bond of the ß-lactam ring, thus inhibiting cell wall synthesis

Drug groups

1. Penicillin

2. Cephalosporin

3. Carbapenems

4. Monobactam (Aztreonam)

Resistance

It occurs through one of the four mechanisms:

  1. Modification of target PBPs (Option A)
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Impaired penetration of drugs to target PBPs
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Antibiotic efflux (Option C)
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Inactivation of antibiotic by lactamases (Option B)

ß-lactamases are enzymes produced by certain bacteria that inactivate ß-lactam antibiotics by hydrolysis of the ß-lactam ring in their structure.

questions.text: Pegloticase is used in the management of?

DOC- NSAIDS

Colchicine

  • MOA: microtubule inhibitor
  • Used in acute attacks of gout and familial Mediterranean fever and is also the DOC for karyotyping

Corticosteroids

  • Immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory

Drugs for chronic gout

Xanthine oxidase inhibitors
  • Drugs include Allopurinol (DOC), Oxipurinol, Febuxostat
  • MOA: Blocks xanthine oxidase enzyme → Inhibits the conversion of hypoxanthine to uric acid in the liver

Uric acid oxidase enzyme
  • Drugs include Pegloticase and Rasburicase
  • MOA: Uric acid is converted to allantoin and excreted in urine

Uricosuric agents
  • Drugs include Probenecid, Benzbromaron, Sulfinpyrazone, Lesinurad
  • MOA: Inhibit OATP transporter/URAT-1 in the kidney → inhibits reabsorption of uric acid → increased excretion of uric acid.

 

(OATP - Organic anion transport protein, URAT-1 - Uric acid transporter)

questions.text: Which of the following is used in first-line management of post-menopausal osteoporosis?
questions.explanation:
Bisphosphonates

1st generation

2nd generation

3rd generation
  • Etidronate
  • Clodronate
  • Alendronate
  • Risedronate
  • Ibandronate
  • Zoledronate
  • Pamidronate

Mechanism of Action

Direct inhibition of osteoclast activity and bone resorption.

Frequency of Administration

More potent drugs require less frequent administration

  • Alendronate: Given once a week.
  • Risedronate: Given once a week.
  • Ibandronate: Given once a month.
  • Zoledronate: Given once a year.

Uses of Bisphosphonates

Condition

Role of Bisphosphonates

Osteoporosis

Effective in preventing and treating postmenopausal osteoporosis, age-related, idiopathic, and steroid-induced osteoporosis.

Paget's Disease

Arrest osteolytic lesions, reduce bone pain, and improve secondary symptoms.

Hypercalcemia of Malignancy

Lower serum calcium levels, especially in severe cases.

Metastatic Bone Disease

Arrest osteolytic lesions and reduce bone pain.

Adverse effects of Bisphosphonates

Bisphosphonates

Adverse effects

Etidronate

Interference with bone mineralisation, potential osteomalacia

Pamidronate

Thrombophlebitis, bone pain, fever, leukopenia, flu-like symptoms.

Alendronate

Esophagitis, gastric erosion, retrosternal pain, flatulence.

Ibandronate

Risk of flu-like symptoms with intravenous infusion.

Risedronate

Generally well-tolerated, potential for gastrointestinal upset.

Zoledronate

Severe hypocalcemia, nephrotoxicity, flu-like symptoms, osteonecrosis of the jaw.
  • Oral Bisphosphonates causes esophagitis: Should be administered on an empty stomach with plenty of distilled water. Patient should not eat anything and should not lie down for 30 minutes - To avoid reflux esophagitis.
  • Bisphosphonates are associated with an increased risk of Subtrochanteric femur fracture.
  • Bisphosphonates are C/I in renal failure.
  • Regular dental check-ups are advised to monitor for osteonecrosis of the jaw.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes developed postoperative urinary retention. Which of the following drugs can be used for short-term treatment of the condition?
questions.explanation:
Bethanechol

Bethanechol is a cholinergic agonist that stimulates muscarinic receptors, which are found primarily in the urinary and gastrointestinal tracts.

MOA
  • Mimics the effects of acetylcholine, which plays a crucial role in the parasympathetic nervous system, at muscarinic receptors.
  • Upon stimulating muscarinic receptors, it promotes bladder muscle contraction, aiding in urine expulsion and reducing urinary retention.

Clinical Usage
  • Postoperative and Postpartum urinary retention with no actual obstruction.
  • Neurogenic bladder.
  • Symptomatic relief in congenital megacolon.
  • Gastroesophageal reflux

Side Effects
  • Gastrointestinal: Belching, involuntary defecation.
  • Urinary: Involuntary urination.
  • Other: Flushing, sweating, hypotension.

Contraindications
  • Mechanical obstruction of the gastrointestinal or urinary tract.
  • Asthma.
  • Hypotension.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by inhibiting the late sodium current in the heart?
questions.explanation:
Ranolazine

MOA
  • Inhibits the late sodium current in cardiomyocytes, which helps to reduce intracellular sodium accumulation during ischemic conditions
  • Indirectly reduces calcium overload in cardiac cells and improves myocardial relaxation, leading to an anti-ischemic effect.
  • It decreases ventricular diastolic tension, reduces myocardial oxygen consumption, and improves myocardial perfusion

Uses

  • Used as add-on therapy as an Antianginal agent for Chronic stable angina.
  • Reduces the frequency of angina pectoris and improves exercise tolerance.
  • Ventricular tachycardia.
  • Improves glycemic control (lower HbA1c and increase insulin)

Adverse effect

  • Dizziness, headache, nausea and asthenia
  • Constipation and Liver failure
  • QT-prolongation and rarely Ventricular arrhythmia such as Torsades de pointes.

A person develops headache and breathlessness on a trekking expedition following a rapid ascent to over 3000 meters above the sea level. Which of the following is not used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Acute Mountain Sickness

Symptoms
  • Headache
  • Nausea
  • Fatigue
  • Insomnia
  • Appear hours to days after rapid ascent

Pathophysiology
  • Associated with cerebral oedema, caused by increased capillary pressure in the brain due to dilation of blood vessels in response to low oxygen levels.
  • The increased permeability of the blood-brain barrier contributes to fluid leakage into brain tissue.

Treatment
  • Descending to a lower altitude (Option B ruled out)
  • Supplemental oxygen (Option C ruled out)
  • Acetazolamide to facilitate acclimatization (Option D ruled out)
  • In severe cases, corticosteroids may be used to reduce cerebral oedema.

questions.text: A maid is playing with a child by spinning him while holding his hands. A few hours later, the child starts crying, does not use his arm, and does not let anybody touch him. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Pulled Elbow (also known as Nursemaid’s Elbow)

Age group

1-5 years (most common)

Mechanism of injury

A sudden jerk or pull on the arm when it is extended and pronated causes the radial head to slip out of the annular ligament (radial head subluxation).

Clinical presentation

The child holds the affected arm close to the body in a slightly flexed and pronated position, resisting movement, particularly supination.

X-ray

  • Diagnosis is usually clinical.
  • X-ray is unnecessary unless there is suspicion of other injuries.
    • It may appear normal
    • If visible, they can show subtle displacement of the radial head, with the possible elevation of the anterior fat pad or visibility of the posterior fat pad, indicating joint effusion.

Treatment

Reduction of the subluxation by supination and flexion or hyperpronation of the forearm typically results in immediate relief.

questions.text: What is the duration of the extended sickness benefit provided to an employee who has been diagnosed with TB?
questions.explanation:
Benefits of ESI(Employees State Insurance) Act.

Medical Benefit
  • Provides "full medical care," including hospitalization at no cost to insured individuals & families in cases of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.

Sickness Benefit
  • Provides 70% of average daily wages in cash during medical leave for a maximum of 91 days within 365 days, as certified by the Insurance Medical Officer/Practitioner.

Extended Sickness Benefit

Extended coverage for long-term diseases beyond 91 days; 34 diseases covered if employed for two years.

Extended sickness benefit is paid at 80% of the insured person's wages.

Enhanced Sickness Benefit
  • Cash benefits (100% wages) for sterilisation procedures:
    • 14 days for tubectomy (women),
    • 7 days for vasectomy (men).

Maternity Benefit
  • Cash payments for childbirth, miscarriage, or pregnancy-related sickness:
    • 26 weeks for childbirth,
    • 6 weeks for miscarriage, and
    • 40 days for pregnancy-related sickness.
  • Paid at 100% of the insured woman's average daily wages.

Disablement Benefit
  • Temporary Disablement Benefit (TDB):
    • 90% of wages paid from day one for temporary employment injury, until recovery.
  • Permanent Disablement Benefit (PDB):
    • 90% of wages paid monthly for life, based on certified loss of earning capacity.

Dependent's Benefit
  • Dependents receive 90% of the deceased's (due to employment injuries) wages as a shared pension, eligible until age 18 or earlier for married daughters.

Funeral Expenses
  • Offers a cash payment up to Rs. 15,000 to cover funeral expenses upon the death of an insured individual.

Rehabilitation
  • Insured individuals and their families are entitled to continued medical treatment even after permanent disablement or retirement.
  • They have to pay a nominal fee of Rs.10 per month to avail this benefit.
  • Rehabilitation allowance of Rs.15,000 granted.

Unemployment allowance
  • For eligible employees due to factory closure or retrenchment: 50% of wage for up to two years.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who was admitted to the intensive care unit 48 hours after fracturing their femur, with a saturation of oxygen in the rebreathing unit at 100%, but their SpO 2 remained at 60%? The patient is also experiencing confusion, and a chest radiograph shows clear lung fields.
questions.explanation:
Fat Embolism
  • Fat embolism is a multi-organ disorder caused by fat globules entering the bloodstream, commonly occurring after high-risk orthopedic injuries, particularly femur fractures.

Classic Triad
  • Hypoxia
  • Petechiae
  • Altered mental status

Other Symptoms

  • Tachycardia, fever, anemia, thrombocytopenia, pulmonary dysfunction (e.g., tachypnea, respiratory acidosis).

Etiology
  • Young adults (20-30 years): Long bone fractures
  • Iatrogenic cause: Occurs after intramedullary (IM) nailing of the femur.

Pathogenesis

  • Following injury, fat from bone marrow or platelet agglutination enters injured vessels and travels as emboli, leading to various clinical manifestations.

Investigation
  • Chest X-ray: Commonly clear lung fields, occasionally Snowstorm appearance is seen (pathognomonic)
  • PaO₂ <60 mm Hg
  • Platelet count <1.5 lakhs
  • ECG: Prominent S-wave
  • Other lab findings: Anemia, hypocalcemia
  • CT scan and MRI: Assess severity

Management

  • Respiratory support: Oxygen or ventilator support to restore PaO₂
  • Drug therapy:
    • Steroids: Reduce lung inflammation and improve gas exchange.
    • Heparin: Lipolytic and antiplatelet agent.
    • Low molecular weight dextran: Increases plasma volume.
    • Antibiotics and other supportive care.
  • Definitive fracture treatment: Early fixation to prevent worsening.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding competitive inhibition?

options.label: A
options.text: The inhibitor binds to an allosteric site on the enzyme.

options.label: B
options.text: Competitive inhibition decreases the apparent Vmax (maximum reaction rate) of the enzyme.

options.label: C
options.text: Increasing substrate concentration can overcome competitive inhibition.

options.label: D
options.text: Competitive inhibition decreases the Km for the substrate

questions.correct_answer: C. Increasing substrate concentration can overcome competitive inhibition.
questions.explanation:
Competitive inhibitors

Clinical Correlation

Methotrexate and Dihydrofolate Reductase

Methotrexate acts as a competitive inhibitor by mimicking dihydrofolate, the natural substrate of DHFR, and binding to its active site, thereby preventing dihydrofolate from binding and inhibiting the enzyme's activity.

Sulfa Drugs and PABA

Sulfa drugs, such as sulfanilamide, competitively inhibit the enzyme dihydropteroate synthase by mimicking para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA), a substrate involved in folic acid synthesis in bacteria.

Ethanol and Alcohol Dehydrogenase

Ethanol can act as a competitive inhibitor of methanol metabolism by competing for the active site of alcohol dehydrogenase. This is used in cases of methanol poisoning.

Captopril and Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme (ACE)

Captopril competes with the natural substrate of ACE, thereby inhibiting the production of angiotensin II, a peptide that increases blood pressure.

Acute Epiglottitis

Croup (Acute Laryngotracheobronchitis)

Diagnosis
  • Visualisation: Red and swollen epiglottis (avoid indirect laryngoscopy to prevent airway obstruction).
  • Lateral Neck X-ray: "Thumb sign" indicating swollen epiglottis.
  • Differentiated based on clinical features (e.g., absence of drooling, voice quality).
  • The "steeple sign" on an X-ray AP view shows a narrowing of the upper airway, often seen in croup.

X-Ray Imaging

Hospitalisation

Required due to the high risk of airway obstruction.

Often necessary due to potential breathing difficulties.

Treatment
  • Antibiotics: Parenteral administration (e.g., ampicillin, third-generation cephalosporins).
  • Steroids: Hydrocortisone or dexamethasone to reduce oedema.
  • Hydration: IV fluids if needed.
  • Humidified Oxygen: Via mist tent or croupette.
  • Intubation or Tracheostomy: In cases of severe respiratory obstruction.
  • Antibiotics: Ampicillin 50 mg/kg/day against the H. influenza virus.
  • Humidification: Helps clear crusts and thick secretions that block the tracheobronchial tree.
  • Steroids: to reduce oedema.
  • Racemic Epinephrine: Used as a bronchodilator.
  • Intubation or Tracheostomy: Considered if obstruction worsens or lasts beyond 72 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following drug abuses can lead to the symptoms described by a 25-year-old male patient who complains of a sensation resembling insects crawling beneath his skin and has presented to the clinic?
questions.explanation:
Cocaine

Origin

Leaves of Erythroxylum coca

Erythroxylum coca plant

Local names

Coke, snow, Cadillac, White lady

Physical properties

Colourless, odourless, crystalline, bitter taste

Mechanism of action
  • It is a potent central nervous system (CNS) stimulant that produces initial euphoria and increased energy, followed by depression as its effects wear off.
  • It enhances alertness and activity while stimulating the autonomic nervous system, leading to increased heart rate and elevated blood pressure.

Route of administration

Snorting, Smoking, IV injection

Signs of abuse
  • Septal perforation
  • Crack hands (multiple blackened, hyperkeratotic lesions on the fingers and palms).
  • Black staining of tongue and teeth

Effects

Stages

1. Stage of excitement

  • Feeling of well-being
  • Loss of depression and fatigue
  • Excited and restless
  • Tingling sensation in hands and feet
  • Increased heart rate
  • Increase in temperature
  • Rapid and deep respiration

 

2. Stage of depression

  • Profuse perspiration
  • Convulsion
  • Reduced respiratory rate

Complications

  • Cardiac arrhythmia
  • Cardiac failure
  • Cardiovascular collapse
  • Cerebrovascular accident
  • Aortic dissection
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Skin necrosis
  • Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Formication (Cocaine Bugs)

Management of fatal dose
  • Maintain airway, breathing and circulation
  • If ingested: Gastric lavage with potassium permanganate
  • If snorted, Wash the nasal mucous membrane with water
  • If injected: Ligature over the injection site
  • Amyl nitrite via inhalation route
  • Thiamine 100 mg IV injection
  • Naloxone hydrochloride 2mg IV injection
  • Symptomatic management for convulsions using barbiturates

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with post–menopausal bleeding. Ultrasonography revealed a mass with a “feeding vessel”, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 22-year-old presents with high-grade fever, confusion, and a purpuric rash. CSF analysis reveals gram-negative diplococci. What is the most likely etiology?
questions.explanation:
Investigation

Findings

Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Analysis

Appearance

Cloudy or purulent

White Blood Cell Count (WBC)

Elevated (pleocytosis), typically >1,000 cells/µL, with predominance of neutrophils

Protein

Elevated

Glucose

Decreased

Gram Stain

Presence of gram-negative diplococci

Culture

Growth of Neisseria meningitidis on chocolate agar or Thayer-Martin agar

Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)

Detection of Neisseria meningitidis DNA

Latex Agglutination Test

Positive for Neisseria meningitidis antigens

Blood Tests

Culture

Growth of Neisseria meningitidis

White Blood Cell Count

Elevated leukocytosis with left shift

Neisseria meningitidis treatment

Empirical Antibiotic Therapy
  • Ceftriaxone or Cefotaxime: First-line treatment for suspected bacterial meningitis, including Neisseria meningitidis.
  • Vancomycin: Added to cover potential penicillin-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae until pathogen identification.
  • Ampicillin: Added if Listeria monocytogenes is suspected, particularly in immunocompromised patients and the elderly.

Definitive Therapy
  • Penicillin G: First choice for confirmed Neisseria meningitidis, given intravenously.
  • Alternative Antibiotics: Continue Ceftriaxone or Cefotaxime if pathogen is susceptible.
  • Duration: Typically lasts 7 days.
  • Dexamethasone: May be used to reduce inflammation and neurological complications, especially if started before or with the first antibiotic dose.

Chemoprophylaxis for Close Contacts
  • Rifampin: 600 mg every 12 hours for 2 days (adults); 10 mg/kg every 12 hours for 2 days (children).
  • Ciprofloxacin: Single dose of 500 mg (adults); not typically used in children.
  • Ceftriaxone: Single intramuscular dose of 250 mg (adults) or 125 mg (children).

Vaccination Prophylaxis
  • Meningococcal polysaccharide vaccines (serogroups A, C, Y, W135): 2 doses for children aged 3-18 months or a single dose for older children and adults.
  • Not given to children less than 2-3 years of age.

Indications for Vaccination
  • Contacts during outbreaks
  • Splenic dysfunction
  • Terminal complement component deficiency
  • International travelers

questions.text: In what procedure is the instrument shown in the image utilized?
questions.explanation:
Procedure

Tubectomy

Description

Surgical procedure for permanent female sterilization

Purpose

To permanently prevent pregnancy by blocking or sealing the fallopian tubes, preventing sperm from reaching the eggs

Method

Laparoscopic Tubectomy (Mini-Laparotomy): Performed using a laparoscope and small incisions to access and block/seal the fallopian tubes.

Tubectomy: Performed through a small incision in the abdomen to access and block/seal the fallopian tubes.

Postpartum Tubal Ligation: Performed immediately after childbirth (cesarean section or vaginal delivery) when the woman is still in the hospital.

Anesthesia

General anesthesia or local anesthesia with sedation, depending on the specific procedure and the patient's condition

Recovery Time

Varies depending on the technique used and the individual patient, but typically a few days to a week

Effectiveness

Highly effective in preventing pregnancy, but a small risk of pregnancy exists, usually due to failure in completely blocking/sealing the fallopian tubes.

Potential Side Effects

Pain or discomfort at the incision site - Infection or bleeding - Injury to surrounding organs (rare) - Rarely, ectopic pregnancy (pregnancy outside the uterus) may occur

Reversal

Tubal ligation reversal (tubal reanastomosis) is possible but success rates vary. It is a complex procedure and may not always result in restored fertility.

Alternative Options

Other reversible contraception methods such as oral contraceptive pills, intrauterine devices (IUDs), implants, and barrier methods.

questions.text: What medication is typically prescribed to treat the condition experienced by a 25-year-old woman who complains of a sensation resembling creepy crawling in her legs? This symptom is more pronounced at night and hinders her ability to sleep. However, she finds relief by either engaging in walking or moving her legs.
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Gabapentin

Restless Legs Syndrome

Explanation
  • It is also known as Willis-Ekbom Disease and is characterised by an uncomfortable sensation in the legs, especially in the evening or at night, which leads to an irresistible urge to move them.
  • The movement temporarily relieves the discomfort, but the symptoms soon return, causing difficulty falling asleep or maintaining sleep.
  • This leads to insomnia, which is a common complaint in patients with RLS.

Clinical Features
  • Sensations that begin after rest
  • Relief of discomfort with movement
  • Worsening of symptoms at night with a distinct symptom-free period in the early morning

Treatment
  • No definite cure, but symptoms can be managed.
  • Movement of affected limbs may provide temporary relief.
  • Treat underlying conditions like peripheral neuropathy, diabetes, or iron deficiency anaemia to control symptoms.

 

Medications:

  • Iron supplements: For RLS linked to iron deficiency. (Option D ruled out)
  • Anti-seizure drugs (first-line treatment):
    • FDA-approved: Gabapentin, enacarbil, and others like pregabalin.
  • Dopaminergic agents:
    • FDA-approved: Ropinirole, pramipexole, rotigotine. (Option A ruled out)
    • Levodopa + carbidopa are used intermittently.
  • Opioids: For severe cases unresponsive to other drugs (e.g., methadone, oxycodone).
  • Benzodiazepines: For better sleep (clonazepam, lorazepam).

 

Lifestyle Modifications:

  • Avoid alcohol, nicotine, and caffeine.
  • Maintain a regular sleep pattern.
  • Engage in moderate exercise.
  • Use leg massage, warm baths, heating pads, or foot wraps for relief.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a first-year MBBS student who presents at the OPD with intermittent episodes of intense sweating and a sensation of imminent danger, commonly experienced before her examinations?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Panic disorder:

Panic disorder

General information
  • More common in females than males.
  • Median age of onset: late adolescence or early adulthood.
  • Familial risk: Highest for early-onset panic disorder.
  • Patients with panic disorder commonly have agoraphobia
  • Panic attacks for more than a month are termed as a Panic disorder.
  • Neurotransmitters that are implicated in the development of panic disorders are norepinephrine, Serotonin, GABA, and Cholecystokinin.

Symptoms
  • Unexpected onset, not tied to specific situations.
  • Duration typically 20–30 minutes, rarely exceeding one hour.
  • Cardiopulmonary symptoms: Shortness of breath, palpitations, chest discomfort.
  • Gastrointestinal symptoms: Nausea, abdominal discomfort.
  • Neurological symptoms: Tremors, dizziness, numbness, tingling sensations.
  • Psychiatric symptoms: Derealization, depersonalization, fear of losing control, fear of dying.
  • Other symptoms: Sweating, chills or hot flashes, flushed sensations

Treatment

Pharmacotherapy:

  • Drug of choice: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors.
  • Other first-line: Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) venlafaxine
  • Second-line: Tricyclic antidepressants, MAOIs, Other Psychotropics - Agomelatine, Buspirone, Mirtazapine.
  • Benzodiazepines: Short-term use as an adjunct to SSRIs.
  • Acute phase – Benzodiazepines such as Lorazepam & Clonazepam.

Psychosocial therapies:

  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)
  • Interpersonal therapy.

Note: Treatment of choice: SSRIs + Psychotherapy (CBT)

questions.text: What diagnosis, according to DSM-,V would be appropriate for a middle-aged female patient who has been experiencing symptoms such as loss of interest in daily activities, weight loss, insomnia, and persistent sadness for a period of six months? Additionally, she reports a single incident of hearing a voice instructing her to commit suicide.

options.label: A
options.text: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

questions.correct_answer: A. Major depressive disorder with psychotic features
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

Psychotic depression

Definition

Major depression disorder (MDD) with psychotic features includes mood disturbance with delusions, hallucinations, or both.

Prevalence

It occurs in approximately 18.5% of MDD patients and increases with age.

Characteristics
  • Higher treatment resistance
  • More suicide attempts
  • Longer illness duration
  • Greater functional impairment
  • Higher relapse rates

Older patients may exhibit more brain atrophy and higher mortality rates compared to non-psychotic patients.

Geriatric Considerations

Patients often show significant cognitive dysfunction; depressive pseudodementia may develop.

Cognitive Impairment

Combination therapy: antidepressants + antipsychotics or ECT is the standard of care.

Treatment Approaches

Monotherapy with SSRIs or TCAs is less effective.

Efficacy of ECT
  • ECT shows high remission rates (up to 95% in psychotic depression) compared to pharmacotherapy.
  • ECT is first-line treatment in case of severe psychotic symptoms and high suicide risk.

Oral candidiasis

Oral candidiasis, commonly known as thrush, is an infection caused by an overgrowth of Candida albicans, a type of yeast.

Presentation

Risk factors

  • Diabetes: Poorly controlled diabetes creates a favorable environment for Candida growth due to elevated blood sugar levels.
  • Neutropenia
  • Immunosuppression: HIV/AIDS, cancer, or immunosuppressive medications increases susceptibility.
  • Use of inhaled corticosteroids
  • Antibiotic Use: Broad-spectrum antibiotics can disrupt normal oral flora, allowing Candida to overgrow.
  • Poor Oral Hygiene: Lead to an increase in fungal colonization.
  • Dry Mouth: Conditions that lead to reduced saliva production can promote candidiasis.

Treatment

Antifungal medications, such as nystatin or fluconazole, along with addressing any underlying risk factors.

questions.text: In which trimester does acute fatty liver manifest most commonly during pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Definition

A rare, life-threatening liver disorder that occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy, characterised by microvesicular fatty infiltration of hepatocytes.

Risk Factors
  • First pregnancy
  • Multiple gestations
  • Male fetus
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Maternal obesity
  • Prior history of AFLP

Clinical Features
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Right upper quadrant pain
  • Jaundice
  • Malaise and fatigue
  • Anorexia
  • Polydipsia and polyuria
  • Ascites (rare)

Investigation

  • Elevated AST, ALT
  • Elevated bilirubin
  • Hypofibrinogenemia
  • Prolonged clotting time
  • High D-dimer
  • Hypocholesterolemia
  • Microscopy: Microvesicular fatty infiltration

Complications
  • Liver failure
  • Renal failure
  • Coagulopathy
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Encephalopathy

Management
  • Immediate delivery of the baby (definitive treatment)
  • Supportive care for the mother: IV fluids, glucose infusion, and blood products for coagulopathy.

questions.text: Identify the investigation and the lesion depicted in the image given below:

options.label: A
options.text: Retrograde cystourethrogram with membranous urethra stricture

options.label: B
options.text: Retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: B. Retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture

Urethral Stricture

Definition

Abnormal narrowing of the urethra causes partial or complete obstruction of urine flow, leading to discomfort and severe complications if untreated.

Causes

Trauma (Most common): Pelvic fractures, falls, accidents, or iatrogenic trauma from prolonged catheterization.

Infections: STIs like gonorrhoea and chlamydia cause urethritis.

Medical Procedures: Urethral surgeries or radiation for pelvic cancers.

Inflammatory Conditions: Chronic inflammation from conditions like lichen sclerosus.

Investigations

Posterior Urethral Stricture: Micturating Cystourethrogram (MCU) to visualize the posterior urethra and bladder during voiding. (Option C & D ruled out)

Anterior Urethral Stricture: Retrograde Urethrogram (RGU).

Emergency Evaluation: Both RGU and MCU may be used in trauma cases or acute urinary retention.

Management

Urethral Dilation: Temporary relief with dilators, often leading to recurrence.

Optical Internal Urethrotomy (OIU): Endoscopic incision at the 12 o'clock position; effective for short bulbar strictures (<2 cm).

Urethroplasty: Surgical excision and reconstruction; the gold standard for recurrent or complex strictures

  • Strictures up to 2 cm: Excision with end-to-end anastomosis.
  • Strictures >2 cm: Excision and reconstruction with buccal mucosa, bladder mucosa, or penile skin.

questions.text: Which of the following causative agents is commonly transmitted by soil and is characterized by the egg in stool, as shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Morphology

 

 

 

 

Adult worm
  • The male worm is 30-45 mm long.
  • The female worm is 40-50 mm long (slightly larger).
  • Appearance:
    • Flesh-colored.
    • Whip-shaped: anterior (3/5) thin and thread-like; posterior (2/5) thick and fleshy (like a handle).
    • The end of the male worms is coiled ventrally.
    • The end of the female worm is straight, blunt, and rounded.
  • Body structure:
    • The anterior portion contains a capillary esophagus.
    • The posterior part contains the intestines and reproductive organs.
  • Lifespan: 5-10 years.

Eggs

 

 

 

 

Characteristics:

  • The eggs appear brown as they are bile-stained.
  • They are barrel-shaped.
  • They have a triple shell with a brown outer layer and a colorless mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum.

Infectivity:

  • Freshly passed eggs contain an unsegmented ovum and are not infective for humans.
  • The egg floats in a saturated salt solution.
  • The fertilized female lays about 5,000 eggs per day.

 

 

 

 

 

Epidemiology
  • Distribution:
    • Worldwide, with higher prevalence in tropical regions.
    • Common in tropical Africa, South America, and Southeast Asia.
    • Widespread in India.
  • Prevalence:
    • An estimated 800 million people are infected globally.
    • While whipworm infections are frequent, whipworm disease is relatively rare.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes disease following traumatic inoculation into the skin?
questions.explanation:
Sporotrichosis

Causative agent

Dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

Epidemiology

Common in gardeners, forest workers, and manual labourers.

Route of transmission

Minor trauma or thorn prick.

Clinical features
  • Chronic infection affects cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue.
  • Lesions form at sites of minor trauma or thorn pricks, starting as nodules.
  • Nodules ulcerate and necrose; infection spreads through lymphatic channels.
  • Lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis: Secondary ulcers on lymph nodes; lymphatics become hardened and cord-like.
  • Systemic dissemination: Can affect bones, joints, and meninges.

Specimens

Aspiration from nodules and biopsy material.

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy:

  • KOH mounts or histopathological sections stained by methenamine silver stain show asteroid bodies (Splendore hoeppli phenomenon)
  • Yeast phase: Cigar-shaped cells.

Culture: Thin septate hyphae with flower-like clusters of small conidia; pear-shaped conidia in rosette-like clusters in mycelial phase.

Serological tests: Helpful for extracutaneous or systemic infections.

Treatment

 

Medications:

  • Itraconazole
  • Terbinafine
  • Amphotericin B: For disseminated infection

Cryotherapy.

questions.correct_answer: B. Surgery is indicated if the aneurysmal diameter is > 55mm
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Surgery is indicated if the aneurysmal diameter is > 55mm:

Management of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)

Aspect

Details

Surveillance
  • Small AAAs (3.0–3.9 cm): Monitor every 2–3 years using ultrasound.
  • Medium AAAs (4.0–5.4 cm): Monitor every 6–12 months with ultrasound.
  • Large AAAs (≥5.5 cm): Surgical intervention recommended; if not, frequent imaging and clinical review.

Medical Management

Risk Factor Modification:

  • Smoking Cessation
  • Blood Pressure Control
  • Cholesterol Management: Statins recommended.

Surgical Intervention (Option C & D ruled out)

Indications for Surgery:

  • Aneurysm Diameter ≥ 55 mm (High risk of rupture)
  • Rapid Growth: > 5 mm increase in six months.
  • Symptomatic AAAs: Consider surgery.

Surgical Options:

  • Open Surgical Repair: Using a Dacron graft, which is durable and has higher morbidity.
  • Endovascular Aneurysm Repair (EVAR): Less invasive, requires long-term surveillance for complications.

questions.explanation:
Kwashiorkor

Marasmus (Option B)

Pitting Edema: Characterized by swelling, often starting in the legs and feet, leaving a persistent indentation when pressed.

Severe Wasting: The child appears extremely thin, with prominent bones and little body fat.

Sugar Baby Appearance: The child may look deceptively healthy due to oedema, despite being malnourished.

Monkey Facies: A sunken appearance of the cheeks due to loss of fat, giving an aged look.

Muscle Wasting: Despite the swollen appearance, muscle loss is present, leading to weakness and hypotonia.

Baggy Pants Appearance: Loose, sagging skin around the buttocks caused by significant muscle and fat loss.

Mental and Neurological Symptoms: The child is apathetic, irritable, and may have feeding difficulties.

Alertness: Children with marasmus remain mentally alert.

Hair Changes: Hair may lose colour, become thin, and show alternating bands of colour ("flag sign").

Absence of Edema: Unlike kwashiorkor, marasmus does not involve swelling or oedema.

Skin Changes: Includes hyperpigmentation, peeling skin ("flaky paint" appearance), and colour changes, particularly in the buttocks, perineum, and thighs.

Hypoglycemia Risk: The liver's reduced capacity to produce glucose increases the risk of low blood sugar.

Gastrointestinal Issues: Anorexia, vomiting, and abdominal distension. Anaemia is present due to nutritional deficiencies.

Hypothermia Risk: The child may struggle to maintain body temperature due to energy depletion.

questions.text: What would be your diagnosis for a 3-year-old male who has the given buccal mucosa findings and subsequently develops a rash after three days?
questions.explanation:
Aspects

Description

Causative agent

Measles (rubeola) is a highly communicable childhood exanthematous illness caused by the measles virus, an RNA virus from the Paramyxoviridae family.

Transmission

Contact with droplet aerosols (through the respiratory tract or conjunctiva)

Pathogenesis

Primary viremia occurs, resulting in infection of the reticuloendothelial system, followed by secondary viremia, which results in systemic symptoms.

Incubation period

8-12 days

Period of infectivity

From 3 days before to 4 days after the rash onset.

Clinical manifestations
  • Common in preschool children
  • Prodromal phase: Fever (before rash), rhinorrhea, conjunctival congestion and a dry hacking cough.
  • Koplik spots, pathognomonic for measles, appear on the 2nd or 3rd day of illness as grey-white, sand-like lesions with surrounding erythema on the buccal mucosa opposite the lower second molars.

Rash

The erythematous maculopapular rash in measles appears on the 4th day, starting behind the ears, along the hairline, and posterior cheeks, then spreading to the rest of the body over the next 2-3 days.

Management

Symptomatic and conservative (antipyretics, maintenance of hygiene, ensuring adequate fluid and caloric intake, and humidification).

Vitamin A reduces the morbidity and mortality of measles.

Radical Nephrectomy: Involves removal of the kidney with Gerota’s fascia, para-aortic nodes, and ureter up to the pelvic brim.

Ablative Techniques

Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) and Cryoablation involve destroying the tumour using extreme temperatures.

(For advanced/ metastatic disease)

The mother brought her 3-year-old daughter to seek medical attention due to the girl's enlarged clitoris. The results of the karyotype test showed a 46XX pattern. What is the probable underlying cause for this condition?
questions.explanation:
21-Hydroxylase Deficiency
  • Most common form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) (90%)
  • Enzyme Affected: 21-hydroxylase

Pathogenesis
  • 21-hydroxylase deficiency impairs the synthesis of cortisol and aldosterone.
  • Low cortisol levels lead to elevated ACTH levels.
  • Elevated ACTH causes the accumulation of steroid precursors, including dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA), androstenedione, and 17-hydroxyprogesterone (17-OHP).

Clinical Manifestations
  • Salt wasting form: Severe deficiency with nearly absent enzyme activity.
    • Presents in neonates with salt-wasting, virilization, ambiguous genitalia in girls, failure to thrive, polyuria, hyperpigmentation, critical electrolyte imbalances and shock. Diagnosis may be missed in boys.
  • Simple virilizing form: Partial enzyme activity (25%) allows aldosterone production.
    • Features include virilization in girls and peripheral precocious puberty in boys.
  • Non-classic form: Mild enzyme deficiency with mild hyperandrogenism. Symptoms include hirsutism, acne, and menstrual irregularities in adolescents.

Diagnosis
  • Salt-Wasting Form: Extreme elevations of 17-OHP levels (10000-20000 ng/dL, normal <200 ng/dL) in the context of clinical signs of adrenal insufficiency.
  • Simple Virilizing and Non Classic Forms: Elevated 17-OHP levels measured before and 60 minutes after an intramuscular ACTH injection (0.25 mg).

Treatment

Salt wasting and virilizing forms treated with

  • Hydrocortisone (10-15 mg/m²/day) and Fludrocortisone (0.1 mg/day).
  • Long-acting glucocorticoid preparations (dexamethasone or prednisolone) may be used after growth and puberty are complete.

Omphalocele

Definition

A congenital defect where the abdominal wall fails to close, leading to herniation of intestinal loops into the amniotic cavity.

M/c in premature/SGA babies

Adjacent to the defect

Associated anatomic defects are uncommon

Associated abnormalities are common and include:

  • Neural tube defect
  • Cardiac abnormalities
  • Chromosomal defect

Detection

  • Identified through fetal ultrasound.
  • Elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels in maternal serum and amniotic fluid.

Elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) concentrations in maternal serum and amniotic fluid, similar to gastroschisis.

Complication

  • Affected bowel loops may be damaged due to exposure to corrosive amniotic fluid.
  • Risk of volvulus, where the bowel twists around itself, compromising blood supply.
  • Feeding difficulties
  • Failure to thrive
  • Inguinal hernias
  • Gastroesophageal reflux
  • Occasionally esophagitis

Prognosis

Favorable

High mortality rates

questions.correct_answer: A. Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A) Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days

Septum Primum

 
  • Formed as a sickle-shaped fold from the roof and dorsal wall of the primitive atrium due to pressure from the bulbus cordis.
  • Grows downward toward the atrioventricular (AV) canal and septum intermedium, fusing with the latter.

Ostium Primum

 

Before the septum primum reaches and fuses with the septum intermedium, a gap (foramen primum) allows blood flow between the right and left atria.

Ostium Secundum

Upper part of the septum primum breaks down, creating a new gap (foramen secundum) before the foramen primum closes. The septum primum now has a free upper edge.

Septum Secundum

Grows down from the roof of the atrial chamber, to the right of the septum primum, overlapping the free upper edge of the septum primum as it grows.

Foramen Ovale Formation
  • Overlapping septa create the foramen ovale, allowing blood to flow from right to left atrium during fetal life, preventing left-to-right flow.
  • Patent throughout fetal life.

Obliteration of Foramen Ovale
  • Post-birth, the left atrium receives oxygenated blood from the lungs, increasing pressure in this chamber greater than the right atrium, causing fusion of the septum primum and septum secundum, closing the foramen ovale.
  • Annulus ovalis (adults) corresponds to the lower free edge of the septum secundum, while the fossa ovalis represents the septum primum.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who is a known case of COPD presented with acute exacerbation and is admitted to the ICU. Which of the following statements is correct with regards to the initial management of this patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. Non-invasive PPV should be given
questions.explanation:
Investigation

Purpose/Findings

Arterial blood gases

Assess severity of hypoxaemia, hypercapnia, acidaemia; guide oxygen therapy and ventilation.

Chest X-ray

Identify complications such as pneumonia, pneumothorax, or pleural effusion.

Management

Details

Oxygen Therapy
  • Administer controlled oxygen at 24% or 28% to maintain PaO2 > 8 kPa (60 mmHg) or SaO2 > 90%.
  • Regular arterial blood gas monitoring to adjust therapy.

Non-Invasive Ventilation (NIV)
  • Safe for mild to moderate respiratory acidosis; helps reduce intubation need and mortality.
  • Not suitable for patients unable to protect their airway.

Bronchodilators
  • Use nebulised short-acting β2-agonists (e.g., salbutamol, terbutaline) with anticholinergics (e.g., ipratropium).
  • If oxygen sensitivity is a concern, use compressed air for nebulisation.

Glucocorticoids
  • Administer oral prednisolone (30 mg for 10 days) to reduce symptoms and improve lung function.Reduces frequency and severity of exacerbations.
  • Consider osteoporosis prophylaxis for repeated courses.

Antibiotic Therapy
  • Indicated for increased sputum purulence, volume, or breathlessness.
  • Use simple regimens (aminopenicillin, tetracycline, macrolide); co-amoxiclav in areas with β-lactamase organisms.

Mechanical Ventilation (Option B)
  • Consider if there is a reversible cause, no prior respiratory failure, or if NIV has failed/contraindicated.
  • Decisions should involve the patient, family, and GP.

Additional Therapy
  • Diuretics for peripheral oedema.
  • Limited evidence for intravenous aminophylline; consider arrhythmia risk.
  • Doxapram may be used short-term for low respiratory rates.

questions.text: A cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification is seen on the MRI. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Craniopharyngioma

  • Craniopharyngiomas are suprasellar tumors that develop from remnants of the craniopharyngeal duct or Rathke’s pouch.
  • It compress Optic chaism leads to bitemporal hemianopia.
  • Adamantinomatous subtype
    • It is more common
    • Seen in children
    • Typically appear as large, lobulated, multiloculated cystic lesions with a small enhancing solid component and calcifications.
  • Papillary subtype
    • Seen in Adults
    • Primarily solid lesion
    • Rarely exhibit calcifications

Pituitary Adenoma (Option B)

Pituitary Microadenomas

  • Less than 10 mm in size.
  • Microadenomas appear isointense to the pituitary on T1-weighted images and slightly hyperintense on T2-weighted images.
  • In dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI, they enhance slowly compared to the surrounding pituitary gland.

Pituitary Macroadenomas

  • Larger than 10 mm in size.
  • Most of the macroadenomas are nonfunctioning.
  • They may cause endocrine disturbances or compress the optic chiasm, leading to bitemporal hemianopia.
  • Typically appear as sellar-suprasellar masses with a “snowman” or “figure of eight” appearance due to a waist at the diaphragma sellae.
  • The sella is usually enlarged.
  • These tumors can invade the cavernous sinuses.

Meningioma (Option C)
  • Meningiomas arise from arachnoidal cap cells in the brain and spinal cord coverings.
  • They are the most common benign intracranial tumors.
  • Most common in females
  • Mostly sporadic but can be linked to NF-2 or prior cranial irradiation.
  • Meningiomas are dural based extra-axial masses that appear isointense to gray matter on both T1 and T2-weighted images.
  • They demonstrate intense homogeneous enhancement on post-contrast imaging, accompanied by a dural tail sign.
  • Characteristic imaging features:
    • CSF cleft sign (thin layer of CSF around the mass)
    • Cortical buckling
    • Widening of the subarachnoid space with visible pial arteries/veins,
    • Hyperostosis or erosion of the calvarium.
    • Mother in law sign (early enhancement during the arterial phase and remain opacified long after the venous phase has passed)
    • Calcification

Oligodendroglioma (Option D)
  • Oligodendrogliomas are diffuse infiltrating glial tumors originating from oligodendrocytes and are characterized by IDH mutations and 1p/19q codeletion.
  • These tumors can be either WHO grade 2 (well-differentiated oligodendrogliomas) or WHO grade 3 (anaplastic oligodendrogliomas).
  • Typically occurs in the frontal lobe.
  • They are slow-growing, non-encapsulated, and tend to infiltrate the overlying cortex.
  • CT: Oligodendrogliomas are isodense to hypodense with calcification
  • MRI: Tumors are hypointense on T1 and hyperintense on T2. They generally do not enhance with contrast

questions.text: A 32-year-old male was diagnosed with achalasia cardia. High-resolution manometry revealed massive, simultaneous, high-pressure contractions of the distal oesophagus. According to the Chicago classification, which type of achalasia does the patient have?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Type III

Chicago Classification of Esophageal Motility (4.0)

Esophageal Disorder

Description

Values

1. Achalasia

Type I

Minimal contractility (Option B ruled out)

IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, 100% failed peristalsis

Type II

Esophageal pan-pressurization (Option A ruled out)

IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, 100% failed peristalsis with ≥ 20% pan-esophageal pressurisation

Type III

Spastic contractions (Option D)

IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, ≥ 20% spastic contractions (DCI > 8,000 mmHg·s·cm)

2. Esophagogastric Junction Outflow Obstruction (EGJOO)

Elevated integrated relaxation pressure (IRP) with preserved peristalsis

IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, some preserved peristalsis

3. Distal Esophageal Spasm (DES)

Premature (rapid) contractions with normal IRP

Normal IRP, ≥ 20% premature contractions (DL < 4.5 s)

4. Hypercontractile (Jackhammer) Esophagus

Extremely strong peristaltic contractions

Normal IRP, ≥ 20% hypercontractile contractions (DCI > 8,000 mmHg·s·cm)

5. Ineffective Esophageal Motility (IEM)

Weak or failed peristalsis

Normal IRP, > 50% ineffective swallows (DCI < 450 mmHg·s·cm for weak peristalsis)

6. Absent Contractility

Complete lack of esophageal contractility

Normal IRP, 100% failed peristalsis

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a known history of DM and HTN on regular medications presents with a history of progressively worsening dyspnoea on exertion. On examination, there’s elevated JVP, positive hepatojugular reflux, crackles at the lung bases, hepatomegaly, ascites and pedal oedema. What is your provisional diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features of Left-Sided vs. Right-Sided Congestive Heart Failure (CHF)

Left-Sided Heart Failure

Right-Sided Heart Failure

Causes:

  • Ischemic heart disease (myocardial infarction).
  • Hypertension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy.
  • Aortic or mitral valve disease.

Causes:

  • Left-sided heart failure (most common cause).
  • Chronic lung diseases (COPD, pulmonary hypertension).
  • Pulmonary embolism.
  • Right ventricular infarction.

In left-sided heart failure, the left ventricle cannot effectively pump blood to the body, leading to a backup of blood into the lungs.

 

Clinical features:

This primarily results in pulmonary symptoms.

  • Exertional dyspnea
  • Orthopnea
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea

 

Pulmonary Congestion:

  • Crackles (rales) heard on auscultation due to fluid in the alveoli.
  • Cough
  • Wheezing (cardiac asthma).
  • Fatigue and Weakness
  • Decreased Exercise Tolerance
  • Limited physical activity due to breathlessness and fatigue.
  • S3 Gallop

 

Cool Extremities: Reduced cardiac output may cause poor peripheral circulation, leading to cold, pale skin.

In right-sided heart failure, the right ventricle fails to pump blood effectively into the pulmonary circulation, leading to systemic venous congestion. It is often secondary to left-sided heart failure or conditions affecting the lungs (cor pulmonale).

 

Clinical Features:

  • Peripheral Edema
  • Jugular Venous Distension (JVD)
  • Hepatomegaly
  • B/L pitting pedal edema
  • Kussmaul sign: JVP elevation on inspiration
  • Ascites
  • Nocturia
  • Weight Gain
  • Anorexia and Nausea

questions.text: A patient complains of neck stiffness and severe headache. The CT image shown below is suggestive of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Presence of blood in the subarachnoid space, typically from a ruptured cerebral aneurysm or trauma.

Clinical Features
  • Sudden, severe headache (often described as a "thunderclap headache")
  • Worst headache ever experienced by the patient.

Etiology
  • Traumatic: Head injuries causing bleeding in the subarachnoid space.
  • Non-Traumatic: Most commonly due to rupture of a cerebral aneurysm.

Initial Imaging

Non-Contrast CT (NCCT): First-line imaging for suspected SAH, effective in the acute setting.

Radiological Findings (NCCT)

Appearance of Blood: Hyperdense (white) compared to surrounding cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

Common Sites for Blood Accumulation:

  • Interhemispheric Fissure
  • Sylvian Fissure
  • Suprasellar Cistern
  • Perimesencephalic Cistern

Distinctive Shape: Blood may take on a pentagon or star shape, referred to as the "Star of Death."

Additional Investigations

CT Angiography: Visualizes potential aneurysms or vascular malformations; useful for rupture suspicion.

Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA): Gold standard for diagnosing cerebral aneurysms; provides detailed vascular images and therapeutic options (e.g., endovascular coiling).

questions.text: Which of the following causes the slowing of conduction in multiple sclerosis?
What is the most frequently encountered neuroendocrine tumour in the pancreas?
questions.explanation:
Insulinoma

Category

Details

Definition

A rare, typically benign tumour of the pancreatic islet cells that produce excess insulin.

Clinical Features

Whipple's Triad:

  • Documented low blood glucose levels during symptomatic episodes
  • Relief of symptoms upon administration of glucose
  • Symptoms often occur during fasting or after exercise

Symptoms of hypoglycemia (e.g., sweating, palpitations, confusion, visual disturbances, seizures)

Diagnosis
  • Gold-standard test for diagnosing insulinoma is a 72-hour fast.
  • Combination of plasma glucose < 55 mg/dL + insulin level ≥ 3 microUnits/mL + C peptide level ≥ to 0.6 ng/mL + proinsulin ≥ 5 pmol/L, + negative sulfonylurea level indicates that the hypoglycemia induction is by hyperinsulinemia
  • Insulin/glucose ratio > 0.4 is diagnostic
  • Imaging:
    • CT, MRI, EUS

Management
  • Surgical resection is the treatment of choice.
  • Medical management with diazoxide or octreotide for non-surgical candidates or unresectable tumours.

questions.text: Which layer is accountable for preserving the moisture and clarity of the cornea?
questions.explanation:
Layers of Cornea

Epithelium

(Option D ruled out)
  • The outermost layer comprises 5-6 layers of non-keratinized, stratified squamous epithelial cells.
  • Acts as a barrier, protecting the cornea and preventing tear fluid from entering the underlying stroma.
  • The basal cells at the limbus are stem cells responsible for regenerating the corneal epithelium.

Bowman’s Membrane
  • Located just beneath the epithelium, this acellular layer is 12 µm thick and composed of densely packed collagen fibrils.
  • It is a protective barrier to the stroma but cannot regenerate if damaged and heals by scarring.

Stroma

(Option C ruled out)
  • Making up about 90% of the cornea's thickness (approximately 0.5 mm thick), the stroma consists of collagen fibrils arranged in parallel layers.
  • These fibrils are embedded in a hydrated matrix of proteoglycans - Chondroitin and Keratan Sulphate (keratan sulphate maintains corneal transparency).

Pre-Descemet's Membrane (Dua's Layer)

  • This layer, discovered in 2013, is about 15 µm thick, acellular, and lies just above Descemet's membrane.
  • It is strong and resistant to air penetration.

Descemet's Membrane (Option A ruled out)
  • A robust basement membrane of the corneal endothelium is made of collagen and glycoproteins.
  • It is tense, but when torn, curls inwards on itself.
  • It can regenerate if damaged and is resistant to trauma and pathological processes.

Endothelium

(Option B)
  • The innermost layer consists of a single layer of flat, hexagonal cells.
  • These cells are crucial for maintaining corneal transparency by regulating fluid balance within the cornea through an active pump mechanism.

questions.text: The drug increasing uveoscleral flow is?

An 80-year-old woman presented with fatigue. Imaging revealed a scleroatrophic gallbladder with impacted stones and a large stone in the common bile duct, causing dilation of the biliary tree. What is the next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediately take up the patient for cholecystectomy

questions.explanation:
Choledocholithiasis

Investigation
  • Ultrasound: Useful for detecting gallstones and CBD dilation but has limited sensitivity for CBD stones.
  • MRCP: Non-invasive, excellent for visualising biliary tree anatomy and pathology.
  • ERCP: Highly sensitive, both diagnostic and therapeutic for CBD stones.
  • PTC: Used when ERCP is not feasible, such as post-gastrectomy patients or unsuccessful ERCP attempts.
  • EUS: Invasive but accurate for diagnosing choledocholithiasis.
  • Blood Tests: ↑ bilirubin, ↑alkaline phosphatase, and ↑white blood cell count indicate choledocholithiasis and possible complications like cholangitis.

Treatment
  • Endoscopic Management: ERCP with sphincterotomy and stone extraction; stenting if necessary.
  • Percutaneous Removal: Used when endoscopic access is difficult.
  • Surgery: Options include laparoscopic and open choledocholithotomy, choledochoduodenostomy, and choledochojejunostomy.

Complications
  • Cholangitis: Bacterial infection due to obstructed bile flow, leading to fever, chills, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice.
  • Pancreatitis: Inflammation of the pancreas due to obstruction at the ampulla of Vater.
  • Liver Damage: Prolonged obstruction can cause biliary cirrhosis and liver failure.
  • Biliary Stricture: Chronic inflammation can lead to the narrowing of the bile ducts.
  • Gallstone Ileus: Large gallstone eroding into the intestine, causing mechanical obstruction.

questions.text: Shifting fluid sign is seen in?
questions.explanation:
Type of Retinal Detachment

Clinical Features

Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment (Option C)

1. Floaters (dark spots) due to rapid vitreous degeneration.

2. Photopsia (flashes of light) caused by retinal irritation from vitreous movements.

3. Gradual visual field loss, initially localized, progressing to total vision loss as detachment spreads.

4. Dark veil/cloud in front of the eye, particularly when detachment reaches the posterior region.

5. Sudden, painless vision loss in large, central detachment.

6. Retinal breaks may be round, horseshoe-shaped, slit-like, or large anterior dialysis.

7. Vitreous pigments (tobacco dusting or Shaffer sign) are seen in the anterior vitreous with posterior vitreous detachment.

8. Old retinal detachment shows retinal thinning, subretinal demarcation lines (high water marks), and secondary intraretinal cysts.

Tractional Retinal Detachment (Option B)

1. Gradual, progressive visual loss

2. Typically painless

3. No associated flashes or floaters

4. Vitreoretinal bands present

5. No retinal breaks

6. Detached area - concave and localized

7. No shifting fluid

Exudative Retinal Detachment (Option A)

1. Painless and sudden or gradual visual loss

2. No photopsia, holes/ tears, folds and undulations.

3. Smooth and convex with pigmentary disturbances

4. Rounded and fixed with neovascularization on the tumor summit.

5. Shifting fluid - changing the position of the detached area with gravity - hallmark feature.

questions.text: What is the likely reason for a patient showing both unilateral and bilateral abducent palsy?
questions.explanation:
Abducens Nerve (cranial nerve VI)

Type

Motor

Origin

Pons (lower border, opposite the pyramid of the medulla).

Course

Functional component
  • General somatic efferent fibres: Arise from the abducent nucleus in the pons and supply the lateral rectus muscle of the eyeball.
  • General somatic afferent fibres carry proprioceptive sensations from the lateral rectus and terminate in the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.

Supply

Lateral rectus muscle of the eyeball

Clinical aspect

  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis leads to abducens nerve palsy
  • Lesion or injury (elevated intracranial pressure) of the abducens nerve results in paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle, leading to:
    • Inability to abduct the eye
    • Diplopia (double vision)
    • Convergent squint (due to the unopposed action of medial rectus)

Retrosternal goitre

Definition
  • A thyroid gland enlargement that extends into the mediastinum behind the Sternum

Types
  • Primary: Ectopic thyroid tissue in the mediastinum (10%)
  • Secondary: Starts from neck and extends retrosternally (90%)

Clinical Features
  • Neck Swelling with Compression Symptoms: Difficulty breathing (tracheal compression) and swallowing (esophageal compression).
  • Pemberton Sign: Facial flushing and increased difficulty breathing when raising the arms due to thoracic inlet compression.

Diagnosis
  • Physical examination: Limited palpation of the lower border of the thyroid swelling.
  • Imaging: Computed Tomography (CT) Scan of the Neck and Chest is IOC to assess the extent of mediastinal involvement and to evaluate compression of surrounding structures.

Management
  • Primary / Recurrent / Large Malignant Retrosternal Goiter - Median Sternotomy (Option B ruled out)
  • Secondary Retrosternal Goiter - Cervical / Neck Incision

questions.text: A mutation in the gene for the aquaporin channel leads to which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Nephrogenic DI

Feature

Central DI

Nephrogenic DI

Primary Polydipsia

Gestational DI

Definition

Deficiency of AVP (Arginine vasopressin) secretion from the pituitary gland.

Kidneys are unable to respond to AVP, even if levels are normal.

Excessive water intake, suppressing AVP secretion.

Increased activity of placental enzyme degrading AVP during pregnancy.

Causes

Acquired: Head trauma, tumours, granulomas, infections, inflammation, toxins, vascular events, hypoxia.

 

Acquired: Drugs (lithium, demeclocycline), metabolic disorders (hypercalcaemia, hypokalaemia), obstruction, vascular issues, granulomas, tumours, and infiltration.

Dipsogenic: Inappropriate thirst, head trauma, brain diseases.

Increased placental vasopressinase activity.

Psychogenic: Psychiatric conditions, compulsive water drinking.

 

Genetic: Mutations in the AVP–neurophysin II or WFS1 genes.

 

Genetic: Mutations in the V2 receptor or aquaporin-2 genes.

Iatrogenic: Belief in the health benefits of excessive water intake.

Basal Plasma AVP

Low or undetectable (<1 pg/mL).

Normal or elevated (>1 pg/mL).

Low due to suppression by excessive water intake.

Low due to increased degradation.

Urine Osmolarity

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Low (<280 mOsm/L) but can temporarily concentrate with fluid deprivation.

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Plasma Osmolarity

Increased

Increased

Decreased

Increased

Fluid Deprivation Test
  • Urine does not concentrate.
  • AVP or desmopressin injection increases urine osmolarity in severe CDI.
  • Urine does not concentrate.
  • AVP or desmopressin injection has no effect on severe NDI.

Plasma osmolarity and sodium increase above normal without urine concentration.

Not typically performed during pregnancy.

MRI

Posterior pituitary bright spot absent or small.

Posterior pituitary bright- spot may be faint or absent.

Posterior pituitary bright spot present.

Not routinely used for diagnosis.

Desmopressin (DDAVP) Trial

Abolishes polyuria and polydipsia; reduces plasma osmolarity/sodium.

No effect on urine output, fluid intake, or plasma osmolarity/sodium.

Eliminates polyuria but not polydipsia, leading to hyponatremia.

Effective in controlling symptoms.

Plasma Copeptin

Low or undetectable.

It may be normal or elevated.

Suppressed due to low AVP.

It may be low due to AVP degradation.

Treatment

Desmopressin (DDAVP).

Thiazide diuretics, amiloride, low-sodium diet, prostaglandin inhibitors.

Behavioral therapy, education about overhydration.

Desmopressin (DDAVP).

Resolution
  • Lifelong treatment usually needed for acquired CDI
  • Genetic forms may improve.
  • Dependent on the underlying cause
  • Lithium-induced NDI may persist.
  • Dependent on behavioural modification and addressing the underlying cause.
  • Usually, it resolves after delivery.

questions.text: An elderly woman is brought to the OPD with complaints of behavioural change, a history of multiple falls, urinary incontinence, and dementia. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH)

NPH is often idiopathic but can result from prior injuries affecting cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) dynamics, such as subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Clinical Triad
  • Gait disturbance: Progressive difficulties in walking
  • Urinary issues: Urgency or incontinence
  • Cognitive impairment: Decline in cognitive functions

Imaging Characteristics
  • Ventriculomegaly is typically seen
  • Evans ratio: the ratio of the maximum width of frontal horns to inner table width of more than 0.31 is often used for evaluation but has low diagnostic accuracy.
  • An acute callosal angle (less than 90°) on coronal MR images is another measurement used, also with limited accuracy.
  • A disproportionately enlarged subarachnoid space hydrocephalus is seen having ventriculomegaly combined with sulcal effacement at the vertex and scattered enlarged sulci.
  • CSF flow study shows hyper-dynamism with a streak of flow void through cerebral aqueduct.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in pituitary apoplexy?
questions.explanation:
Pituitary apoplexy

Pathology

  • Acute intra-pituitary hemorrhage resulting in an endocrine emergency
  • It may arise spontaneously in preexisting adenomas, occur postpartum or be associated with conditions like diabetes, hypertension, sickle cell anemia, or acute shock.
  • Severe ↓ ACTH and GH, other hormones may be ↓ or normal

Clinical features

  • Severe headache
  • Central nervous system (CNS) hemorrhage
  • Signs of meningeal irritation
  • Loss of consciousness (secondary to adrenal insufficiency and shock) (Option C)
  • Bilateral visual changes
  • Ophthalmoplegia (eye muscle paralysis)
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hypotension (Option A)
  • Shock
  • Cardiovascular collapse

Management

  • High-dose glucocorticoids are the first line of treatment to correct adrenal insufficiency, stabilize blood pressure, and correct hypoglycemia.
  • Patients without evident visual loss or impaired consciousness can be managed conservatively with high-dose glucocorticoids.
  • Urgent surgical decompression: Required for patients with significant or progressive visual loss, cranial nerve palsy, or loss of consciousness.
  • Monitoring: Visual recovery is inversely correlated with the duration of time after the acute event, so timely intervention is crucial.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and a barking cough for 5 days. Chest X-ray findings suggest the diagnosis. What is the causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup)

Refers to viral infection of the glottic and subglottic regions.

Causative Agent
  • Parainfluenza viruses (types 1,2 and 3) cause about 75% cases.
  • Other Viruses:
    • Influenza A and B,
    • Adenovirus,
    • Respiratory syncytial virus,
    • Measles.

Age Group
  • Most common in children aged 3 months to 5 years.
  • Peak incidence occurs in the 2nd year of life.

Initial Symptoms

These symptoms last 1-3 days before development of upper airway obstruction signs and symptoms.

  • Upper Respiratory tract infection
  • Rhinorrhea,
  • Pharyngitis,
  • Mild cough,
  • Low-grade fever.

Progressive Symptoms

  • Barking cough,
  • Hoarseness,
  • Inspiratory stridor,
  • Fever may reach 39-40°C (102.2-104°F) or be absent.
  • The child prefers to sit up in bed or be held upright.
  • Symptoms worsen at night, recur over days and resolve within a week.

Physical Examination Findings
  • Hoarse voice,
  • Coryza,
  • Normal to moderately inflamed pharynx.
  • Slightly increased respiratory rate.
  • Hypoxia and low oxygen saturation seen only in complete airway obstruction.

Diagnosis

  • Clinical diagnosis
  • X-ray PA view of neck: Steeple sign, which is characteristic of subglottic narrowing

Treatment

  • Mainstay of Treatment: Focus on airway management and hypoxia treatment.
  • Mild croup: Single dose dexamethasone.
  • Moderate to severe croup: Nebulized epinephrine in addition to dexamethasone.
  • Nebulized Racemic Epinephrine: Used for moderate to severe stridor at rest, possible need for intubation, respiratory distress and hypoxia.
  • Corticosteroids:
    • Decrease edema in laryngeal mucosa
    • Oral steroids beneficial in mild croup
    • Dexamethasone 0.6 mg/kg single dose; as low as 0.15 mg/kg may be effective.
  • Antibiotics are not indicated.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 60-year-old man who is grieving the loss of his wife and expressing guilt, believing his intestines have deteriorated and that he deserves to be imprisoned? He also reports persistent sadness and a lack of interest in daily activities since his wife's passing.
questions.explanation:
Psychotic depression

Definition

Major depression disorder (MDD) with psychotic features includes mood disturbance with delusions, hallucinations, or both.

Prevalence

Occurs in approximately 18.5% of MDD patients and increases with age.

Characteristics
  • Higher treatment resistance
  • More suicide attempts
  • Longer illness duration
  • Greater functional impairment
  • Higher relapse rates

 

Older patients may exhibit more brain atrophy and higher mortality rates compared to non-psychotic patients.

Geriatric Considerations

Patients often show significant cognitive dysfunction; depressive pseudodementia may develop.

Cognitive Impairment

Combination therapy: antidepressants + antipsychotics or ECT is the standard of care.

Treatment Approaches

Monotherapy with SSRIs or TCAs is less effective.

Efficacy of ECT
  • ECT shows high remission rates (up to 95% in psychotic depression) compared to pharmacotherapy.
  • ECT is first line treatment in case of severe psychotic symptoms and high suicide risk.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department with respiratory distress and hypotension following a trauma. He has subcutaneous emphysema, and there is an absence of air entry into the right side of the lungs. What is the next best step?

options.label: A
options.text: Start IV fluids with a large bore cannula

options.label: B
options.text: Needle decompression into the 5 th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line

options.label: C
options.text: Take the patient to the ICU and intubate him

questions.correct_answer: B. Needle decompression into the 5 th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line
questions.explanation:
TENSION PNEUMOTHORAX

Pathophysiology
  • D/t ‘one-way valve’ air leaks from the lung or chest wall.
  • Air is sucked into the thoracic cavity without any escape, collapsing and compressing the affected lung.
  • The mediastinum shifts to the opposite side, reducing venous return and compressing the opposite lung, leading to decreased cardiac output and function. This can result in sudden death.

Causes
  • Penetrating Chest Trauma.
  • Blunt Chest Trauma with parenchymal lung injury and persistent air leak.
  • Iatrogenic Lung Injury (e.g., central venepuncture)
  • Mechanical Positive-Pressure Ventilation.

Clinical Features
  • Tachypnea and Tachycardia
  • Hyper-resonance and Decreased/Absent Breath Sounds
  • Resonant Percussion with severe mediastinal/tracheal shift
  • Cyanosis and Hypotension
  • Chest Pain
  • Distended Neck Veins
  • Subcutaneous emphysema

Emergency Management
  • Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed by waiting for radiological confirmation.
  • Immediate Thoracocentesis (needle): Wide bore needle (typically a 20- or 22-gauge) in the 5th intercostal space in the safety triangle.
  • Decompression should be performed in the "safe triangle."
    • Safe Triangle Boundaries:
      • Posterior: Latissimus dorsi
      • Anterior: Lateral border of the pectoralis major
      • Inferior: A line drawn perpendicularly from the nipple to the back, just anterior to the mid-axillary line.

  • In critical situations, a finger thoracostomy can be done in the same location.
  • Nasal Oxygen for support.
  • Intercostal Tube Placement (ICT) once stable and confirmed by chest X-ray.

Additional Care

  • Antibiotics and analgesics for treatment.
  • Ventilator Support with IPPV in severe cases.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Fimbriae are thin, hair-like appendages found on the surface of many bacteria, primarily Gram-negative bacteria.

Structure

Fimbriae are composed of protein subunits called pilins. They are usually shorter and more numerous than flagella.

Types
  • Common (Type I) Fimbriae: Adhesive fimbriae that bind to mannose-containing receptors on host cells.
  • Sex Pili: Involved in bacterial conjugation and DNA transfer.

Functions
  • Adhesion: Fimbriae allow bacteria to adhere to surfaces, cells, and tissues, which is crucial for colonization and infection.
  • Biofilm Formation: Contribute to biofilm formation, protecting bacteria from environmental stresses.
  • Gene Transfer: Sex pili facilitates the transfer of genetic material between bacteria during conjugation, promoting genetic diversity and the spread of antibiotic resistance.
  • Motility: Usually not involved except Type IV Pili, particularly in Neisseria species, enabling a type of movement known as twitching motility.

Uses in Medicine
  • Target for Vaccines: Components of fimbriae can be used as antigens in vaccines to prevent bacterial infections.
  • Antimicrobial Targets: Inhibiting fimbrial function can prevent bacterial adhesion and biofilm formation, making it a potential target for new antibiotics.

Clinical Importance
  • Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs): Uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC) use Type 1 fimbriae to adhere to the urinary tract, causing UTIs.
  • Respiratory Infections: Bacteria like Bordetella pertussis (whooping cough) use fimbriae to adhere to the respiratory tract.
  • Gastrointestinal Infections: Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) use fimbriae to adhere to the intestinal mucosa, causing diarrhea.
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Uses Type IV pili for surface attachment and biofilm formation.
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Uses fimbriae for attachment to mucosal surfaces in the genitourinary tract.

Laboratory Identification
  • Hemagglutination Assay: Detects Type 1 fimbriae by their ability to agglutinate red blood cells.
  • Electron Microscopy: Visualizes fimbriae on the surface of bacteria.
  • Pellicle Formation: Observing pellicle formation on liquid culture surfaces can indicate the presence of fimbriae.

questions.text: What antenatal complication can be anticipated in the mother of the first baby, considering the second baby is a healthy newborn?
questions.explanation:
Complication

Description

Macrosomia

Large birth weight of the baby (over 4,000 grams or 8 pounds 13 ounces), which can increase delivery complications.

Shoulder dystocia

Difficulty delivering the baby's shoulders after the head is delivered, which can lead to birth injuries and complications.

Neonatal hypoglycemia

Low blood sugar levels in the newborn due to elevated insulin levels during pregnancy.

Preterm birth

Delivery of the baby before 37 weeks of gestation, which increases the risk of health problems for the baby.

Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS)

A breathing disorder in premature babies due to immature lungs.

Jaundice

A yellowing of the baby's skin and eyes caused by high bilirubin levels.

Preeclampsia

High blood pressure and organ damage in the mother during pregnancy.

Type 2 diabetes later in life

Increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes for both the mother and the child later in life.

Increased risk of obesity and metabolic syndrome

Greater likelihood of the mother and child developing obesity and metabolic disorders.

questions.text: What does the given barium swallow film show?
questions.explanation:
Zenker's diverticulum

Clinical features:
  • Dysphagia is the most prominent feature appears when the pouch gets filled with food and presses on the oesophagus.
  • Gurgling sound is produced on swallowing.
  • Regurgitation at night from undigested food causes cough and aspiration pneumonia.
  • Halitosis(Chronic bad breathe)
  • Malnourished due to dysphagia.
  • Associated hiatus hernia

Diagnosis:
  • Barium swallow provides information regarding the size, location, and character of the mucosal lining.

  • Endoscopy reveals fibrosis and pooling of food in the diverticulum.

Treatment:

 
  • Excision of the pouch and cricopharyngeal myotomy was done through a cervical approach.
  • Dohlman’s procedure: Partition wall between the oesophagus and the pouch is exposed and divided by diathermy through a weerda scope.
  • Endoscopic laser treatment: Partition wall between the oesophagus and the pouch is exposed and divided by CO2 laser using an endoscope. This procedure is known to have fewer recurrences and faster improvement in symptoms.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with recurrent episodes of fever with chills. The MRCP image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC)

PSC is characterised by inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of extrahepatic and large intrahepatic bile ducts, with dilation of preserved segments.

Demographics
  • It commonly occurs in individuals aged 30-50 years.
  • Has a male predominance of 2:1.

Pathogenesis
  • It suggests an immunologically mediated process supported by circulating autoantibodies and T lymphocytes in the periductal stroma, as well as associations with HLA-B8 and ulcerative colitis.
  • A mix of environmental & genetic factors may trigger bile duct injury.
  • Increased risk of PSC in first-degree relatives indicates a genetic component.
  • Activated T cells from ulcerative colitis mucosa may migrate to the liver, targeting bile duct antigens.
  • Changes in the intestinal microbiome or infections may alter cholangiocytes, causing inflammation.
  • Atypical perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (pANCA) are

Clinical features
  • Common symptoms include fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice.
  • Nearly 50% of patients are asymptomatic at diagnosis, often identified through elevated serum alkaline phosphatase.
  • Ascending cholangitis, chronic pancreatitis, and chronic cholecystitis may also occur.
  • Fibrosis can progress to cirrhosis over 10-15 years.

Characteristic findings
  • ERCP/MRCP shows the beaded appearance of bile ducts
  • Biopsy,
    • Early features:
      • Periductal "onion skin" fibrosis & inflammation
      • Portal edema & bile ductular proliferation
    • Later stages show progressive fibrosis leading to biliary cirrhosis and obliterative cholangitis, resulting in "vanishing bile duct syndrome"

Associated conditions

Ulcerative colitis, risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma

Complication

Lifetime risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma is about 20%.
